did.unittitle: Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia Botany Department records

bioghist.p: The Botany Department of the Academy of Natural Sciences conducts research on plant biodiversity and evolution, and maintains the Academy's herbarium. Because the Academy was one of the first scientific institutions in the New World, the herbarium holds some of the oldest and most important plant collections in the Americas. The herbarium contains about 1.5 million dried, pressed specimens and plays a vital role as a resource for research on plants and on the history of American botany.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of records related to the Academy's Botany department. Materials include general files and departmental correspondence dating from the 1970s and 1980s from the offices of James Mears, Alfred E. Schuyler, Joan Apfelbaum, Helen Greenwood, and others. The collection includes earlier correspondence of Alexander MacElwee, Walter Benner, C.D. Fretz, and others, related to the acquisition and identification of specimens (1877-1920). Notebooks and catalogs of the Botany Department include: a paleobotany catalog, 1971-1975; an index to ferns at the Academy, 1880; a catalog of lichens; catalogs of the Arthur Leeds, S.S. Van Pelt, and William M. Thompson collections; exchange books; a telephone and address book; herbarium notebooks (1934-1936, 1937-1943); accession catalogues of the University of Pennsylvania Herbarium (which is incorporated in the Academy) (1891-1970); a catalog, on microfiche, of the department's special collections, including type specimens; CD-ROMs of the Lewis and Clark Herbarium; 8-inch diskettes (IBM o/s 6) containing an inventory of the Muhlenberg Herbarium, 1984; and photocopies of the specimen catalogues for the Wagner Free Institute of Science Herbarium, which is held at the Academy (the original catalogs are at the Wagner). Other records in the collection are the notebooks and collection lists of Ida. K. Langman, from Monroe County, Pennsylvania, and Mexico; photographs of fungi by E. Sterling, circa 1920; manuscripts and other documents related to nomenclature; notes and publications by Joan Apfelbaum, 1970s; a photocopy of a handwritten bibliography, "Historical Bibliography of Botanists represented in ANSP Botany Collections," by A. E. Schuyler; and Schuyler's files on small projects and small contracts from 1974 to 1997. Most of these projects were conducted at local sites; the records include ecological studies and lists of plants observed or collected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
